utterances: This idea of being taken for granted as a voting bloc, it's not new.

What's different this year is the ongoing debate in the Democratic Party about whether its focus on people of color in 2016 came at the expense of the white, working-class vote and what it will take to bring back those white voters in 2020.
To Michelle Neely, it's underscored by the new progressive activism she says hasn't always been there for black voters.
When it's time - when there's LGBTQ folks, when there's immigrants, when there's kids being torn away from family - we show up.
When it's us - criminal justice - people are like ah, well.
UNIDENTIFIED PERSON #3: Yeah.
When it's black-specific, white folks...
UNIDENTIFIED PERSON #4: Well, you know, I got this thing this weekend.
...Stop showing up.
And that list of issues important to black women voters isn't that long or unfamiliar.
Several women, including Rabiah Burks, brought up mass incarceration and criminal justice.
Every election cycle, no one wants to touch criminal justice because they don't want to affect their chances of being re-elected.
If black women had a choice - if we had a stronger voice, this would actually be an urgent issue.
And that's what it's actually missing is urgency.
There's nothing else to it.
Ayesha Williams added racial profiling by law enforcement as well.
Like, I've broken up relationships in the middle of a dinner party because - I was dating a police officer - and the other police officers say something like - well, he fit the profile.
And I'm like - my daddy is 6-2.
My brother is 6-3.
They are both dark-skinned with beards, slim build.
I was just like, every man in my family fits the profile.
But these women also talked about education and, like many other voters, the cost of health.
More than anything, Rabiah Burks resented the implication that it's a zero-sum game, that anyone has to lose out when it comes to a candidate reaching out and asking for a vote.
You have to show up to the community every now and then and say, hey, I'm with you or something.
Like, if all of your resources and all of your dollars are going to convince people who are not necessarily with you, then you make the other group feel like they're not even worth being heard.
This is all part of a wider debate in the Democratic Party about the idea of identity politics, so I reached out to California Congresswoman Barbara Lee.
Right now, she's making her own bid to be part of the leadership of the Democratic caucus in Congress.
I asked her what excuses she's heard over the years for the party taking black women voters for granted.
It's interesting because they don't give an excuse because they don't even think about it.
And I think that's part of the problem.
They take us for granted.
And over the years, it's been up and down, up and down.
But for the most part, I don't believe that - until now at least - there's been a recognition of the value of African-American women, not only to the Democratic Party but to the country.
Is there something specific to this moment that you think is forcing the party to take this voter bloc more seriously?
I think, in this moment, we saw major wins in Alabama and in Virginia.
African-American women led the effort to, you know, make sure that we won both of those races.
And so black women have decided that, you know, no longer are we going to be behind the scenes helping others.
In this instance this year, we see brilliant black women running for Congress around the country and for a variety of state and local offices.
And that's a major breakthrough.
And I think we have just said, enough is enough.
What are black women getting out of voting for Democrats?
We definitely have heard from you what Democrats are getting out of it.
Well, black women - I tell you, voting for Democrats - first of all, look at the alternative in terms of what they're getting out of the Republicans.

But when you look at the policies that the Democrats champion - right now especially, as it relates to education, health care, housing, reducing the cost of prescription drugs, it was Democrats who have fought to make sure that insurance companies don't deny coverage to anyone, especially African-American women, as it relates to pre-existing conditions.
Who has these pre-existing conditions disproportionately?
It's African-American men and women.
And so I think when you look at the agenda of the Democratic Party, why we haven't gotten there yet where we should in terms of equality and justice for all, that's our agenda.
And that's our platform.
When you look at the Republicans, they're just the opposite.
And so you know, as a Democrat and as a progressive Democrat, I'm trying to make our party more responsive, more inclusive and more progressive.
And that will help African-American women achieve parity, equity and justice in this country, as it will for everyone.
NPR'S Rachel Martin has the story from Berlin.
Can you talk to the criticism that people feel like the Democratic establishment isn't always very good at backing black women candidates?
The most famous example this cycle was Ayanna Pressley in Boston, who did not get the support of the Congressional Black Caucus' own PAC.
Well, the CBC is a separate entity from the CBC PAC.
So when you look at the firewalls, there are several organizations that are not CBC directed.
And so the political action committee of the CBC, the board makes decisions on who to back and who not to back.
But Ayanna is a very smart, brilliant black woman politician with a lot of experience.
And she showed that she could take on the establishment and win.
And that's what black women are doing all around the country.
This is a new day.
The old way doesn't work anymore.
And we're going to see more and more of that.
California Congresswoman Barbara Lee, thank you for speaking with us.
Thank you.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
This is DAY TO DAY from NPR News.
I'm Robert Smith.
And I'm Alex Cohen.
Sixty-five years ago this summer, a submarine named the USS Grunion disappeared.
Lieutenant Commander Mannert Abele led a crew of 70 on the sub, which patrolled the waters off Alaska's Aleutian Islands World War II.
For years, family members of the sub's crew were left to wonder what happened.
Then Commander Abele's three sons hired a company to find the USS Grunion.
After five years of searching, they believe they finally found it.
And as Bruce Abele says, that discovery was no small feat.
It's not exactly the easiest place to get to.
I mean, just to get a feel of it.
If you go from Anchorage to Dutch Harbor by plane it takes three hours.
Then you get on a boat and you go for three days to get out there.
So it's a very, very difficult place to get to.
You can't fly there.
The fog is so bad there's no way to land.
And the winds, for example, there was one day there was a gale force wind and they were gusty at 74 miles an hour.
Tell us how exactly you found the USS Grunion.
It was a two-stage effort.
Last August, we went looking for it with the help of a company called Williamson Associates with side scan sonar.
And what that does is you drag it along at the bottom of the ocean - it's almost a mile down and it shows up on a monitor, sort of a blips on the monitor.
And the blips gave us a pretty good clue because it was almost exactly where we predicted it should be.

And then what we did this year is we went back again in August and this time we went with an ROV, which is a remote operated vehicle, but basically it's a camcorder, and videotaped and took digital photographs of the target that we found last year.
How can you be sure that it's the Grunion?
Are there any numbers on it you can identify or something like that?
No.
You can't see people on that at all.
There's no - first thing, it's the only sub that - the American sub lost on that area.
Number two, it's the exactly almost precisely where we predicted it would be.

Number three, if we found a number of characteristics of that class of sub, though it's very early in the investigation, we have some 700 photographs and we have three and a half hours of high-definition video which hasn't even been processed yet.
But we'll take advantage of having a lot of experts take a look at it.
But there's really no question about it that it's the Grunion.
May I ask how much this mission has cost you at this point?
You could ask but we won't tell you.
It's a secret.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Okay.
Fair enough, fair enough.
I can't imagine it would be an inexpensive endeavor.
Can I ask what inspired you and your two brothers to take on this quest?
Well, a little bit because we could and it means a great deal far more than just our own personal interest.
It meant a great deal to the relatives of the Grunion.
And as of the day that we went back and relocated, we have a group of three women that are just unbelievable.
I called them the sub ladies.
And they have located relatives for every single one of the crew.
And that is a very significant effort.
And when you talk with these people, the significance of something like this happening is just mind-boggling.
Do you have any sense of how the ship was destroyed?
No.
That is the big question.
We are very surprised because we expected it to be completely intact and it is almost exactly the opposite.
The first 24 feet of the bow appear to be gone.
We're going to be careful of when we make these statements because we're really analyzing, at this point, from photographs and from, you know, kind of cursory looks at the video.
What do you plan to do with the submarine now that you've found where it is?
First thing is international law says don't touch it.
We absolutely honor it.
We would agree with that law completely.
We have no intention of disturbing it in any way.
We also have no intention of going back again.
We may have a memorial of some type for the now very enlarged family of the Grunion.
But as far as going back and do anything with the sub, that's not in the plans.
Bruce Abele is the son of USS Grunion's Lieutenant Commander Mannert ""Jim"" Abele.
Thank you so much for speaking with us.
Thank you very much.
Exactly one year ago, President Trump publicly vowed to win the war in Afghanistan even though he said his original instinct was to pull out.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
We must achieve an honorable and enduring outcome worthy of the enormous price that so many have paid.
